social_posts.post_text:
"Sinful." "Unattractive." "Failing."

I honestly can't get over the original quote.

I've been working on a Fixed it For You book (should be ready in February!), with 20 of my favourite ones, and 10 all new ones, to use as a devotional, a conversation starter with your spouse, or even small group curriculum.

I found most of the Fixed it for Yous easy to come up with commentary and questions.
But this one just left me speechless for a while.

It's absolutely stunning how some evangelical men can seem so proud of the fact that they disdain women.

This particular author has also written for The Gospel Coalition and Desiring God, which perhaps shouldn't surprise us. And he's with a Reformed publisher.

To all the women who have felt ashamed of their bodies; who haven't gone for medical help when things seem out of whack because you feel ashamed to talk about it, or assume that it's supposed to be this bad; who have been told you're too "hormonal" to be taken seriously--

Just know that is not how God sees you.

And when "Christian" men say these things--they reveal they aren’t like Christ at all. 

PS: Stay tuned in the new year for more information on the first of many Fixed it for You books!

Pssttt....your husband isn't Jesus.

This really shouldn't be rocket science, but too many elements of evangelicalism actually promote idolatry.

The verse that MacArthur uses--submit to your own husband as to the Lord--was actually revolutionary. The culture told women to obey. Paul merely said "submit". He wasn't going to overthrow the culture (any more than he overthrew slavery), but he told women to keep their focus on God.

To think that Paul is actually telling women to follow their husbands as if they were Jesus goes against everything we know from the Bible about how God wants to relate to us.

He does not share his glory with another. (Isaiah 42:8)

We have no mediator between humanity and God except for Jesus. (1 Timothy 2:5)

We are all to serve God, first and foremost. (Deut. 6:13).

His sheep know His voice and follow Him--so we follow Jesus, all of us, not just the men. (John 10:4)

We must obey God, not men (Acts 5:29).

Women follow God. Men follow God. Husbands and wives follow God together. 

Some people say that the way that women follow God is by following their husbands. But this is explicitly against Acts 5:29 and 1 Timothy 2:5.

Women follow God by following God.

God is God.

Your husband is not.

One of these things is not like the other, and to confuse them is idolatry.

Let's not do that.

Has sex become our idol? Become our god?

This is so repugnant. 

The Act of Marriage was the book that messed me up before I was married. It's sold well ever since it was written, and has gone through four different updated editions.

And no one thought to take this anecdote out.

Tim LaHaye admits that this man beat his teenage son. And he tells how the woman lost her ability to orgasm because she was traumatized by how the husband treated the son--who has since moved away and wants nothing to do with either parent.

Yet the solution? She has to repent of her bitterness. And he praises her because she did, and now their sex life is restored.

There is no commentary on how the husband was abusive.

No commentary on how the wife is likely not safe either.

No commentary on how the husband's behaviour has stolen her son from her.

No commentary on the steps the woman should take to make sure she and any other children are safe.

Just stop being bitter, and keep having sex.

If a husband beating a teenage son isn't enough to warrant not having sex, what exactly is?

This book should not be in print. This isn't even the worst of the anecdotes. My dedication in The Great Sex Rescue is to Aunt Matilda, another character in The Act of Marriage who was a victim of marital rape--and Tim LaHaye made her the bad person in that story.

Seriously, if you have issues with sex and you grew up in the evangelical world, just know it's not your fault. You likely internalized this toxic stuff.

We all did. I certainly did. This was the book that wrecked me. 

But I'm better now. And I hope The Great Sex Rescue can help you see the toxic stuff you may have internalized, and help set you free!

When we say, "God wants you to prioritze sex in marriage," what are we really saying? 

When we stress that sex should be frequent, but we make no mention of the 47 point orgasm gap between men and women in the evangelical church, and we make no mention of the fact that 18% of women report that their primary feeling after sex is feeling used, then we're diminishing sex. We're ignoring intimacy. And we're misunderstanding God.

It isn't one-sided intercourse that God wants us to prioritize. 

It's sex that is MUTUAL, INTIMATE, and PLEASURABLE FOR BOTH. Her feeling used isn't glorifying God or helping your marriage. Her feeling no pleasure and being ignored isn't glorifying God or helping your marriage.

As this brilliant commenter said so well on the blog, we need to understand what pleases God. It isn't merely intercourse. It's the unity and love that real sex is supposed to bring.

We can get this right this new year!

Check out our research in The Great Sex Rescue, and learn a way of reframing how we talk about sex. And if you're a pastor--this is absolutely crucial! Watch what you say. Because if you merely talk about "how important sex is," people are going to think that one-sided intercourse is okay.

You don't defeat porn by becoming porn.

Look, if a woman wants to do a boudoir photo shoot, more power to her! I have absolutely no problem if someone wants to do it.

But we need to be careful here.
 In Gary Thomas & Debra Fileta's book Married Sex, there's a section with two stories of women who either texted nude photos to their husband or had these photos taken. And the authors are presenting this as something other women should emulate. 

The first woman, Abby, is reluctant, but she realizes she doesn't want to "unnecessarily deny him." The second woman, Izzy, does this boudoir photo shoot, and the reasoning they give is so that he won't be tempted by other naked women. She can be so hot he doesn't want anyone else because his brain is fixated on her.

This is coercion.

Again--if you want to send nude photos, that's fine! But people who want to send nude photos don't need to be convinced. And this book appears to try to talk women into it, either because it makes a husband happy and you wouldn't want to deny him, or so that he doesn't get tempted by other women's bodies.

They do have a footnote that sending nude photos can be risky, but it's only a footnote.

Meanwhile, revenge porn is a thing. Hacking is a thing. Your kids seeing stuff is a thing. Blackmail is a thing.

Christian authors should not be talking up how great it is to text nude photos to their husbands. We should be issuing warnings about solidifying objectification; about the dangers of it coming into the wrong hands; about how women are not responsible for men not watching porn. We can do better than this, and I hope the tide is turning in 2023.

Is there an acceptable quota for rape in marriage?

In their book Every Heart Restored, Fred Stoeker, along with co-author Steve Arterburn, talk about how some husbands coerce their wives into intercourse several times a day. Their takeaway? Demanding sex MORE than once a day is a sign of a lust problem.

Language matters. Wanting sex? Fine. Asking for sex? Okay. 
But demanding sex? That's NEVER okay.

Demanding sex is ALWAYS abusive.

Demanding sex is coercive.

Rape is not bad ONLY when it exceeds an acceptable quota. It is ALWAYS bad.

One of the big reasons the "Every Man's Battle" series of books doesn't work is that the authors actually don't seem to understand what sex is.

They think sex is something that men need and women provide.

But sex should be something INTIMATE, MUTUAL, and PLEASURABLE FOR BOTH.

When you see sex as transactional—she gives and he takes—it's easy to see how demanding sex can become a thing. It's something he "needs", right? And, after all, she is his methadone to get him to stop watching porn (that's also in their books). And giving him release helps him not sin (also in the book).

This is the objectification of women. It's the nullification of the work of the Holy Spirit in our lives. It needs to stop!

And for more on how to stop it, please see The Great Sex Rescue! It's only $2.39 on Kindle right all month--and it's $5 off in paperback too!

How do you convince a wife to put up with a miserable marriage?

You tell her that it's wrong to expect anything better. You tell her that having any expectations in marriage is really just idolatry. You tell her that she should be happy to suffer for Christ's sake, and that if she expects her husband to treat her well or to open up emotionally, she is tearing down the walls of her own house.

And all too often, it is women in the evangelical world giving this message to other women.

Martha Peace's book The Excellent Wife is big in many biblical counseling circles, and Peace herself teaches counseling through the Association of Certified Biblical Counselors.

That's scary, because this advice is not healthy. God made us with a basic need for intimacy. It is not wrong to expect intimacy with our spouse. If we are feeling lonely in marriage, the answer is not to tell people, "you are being idolatrous." It is to teach people how to make their needs known; how to draw boundaries; how to communicate well; how to work through any trauma they may have; and how to seek licensed counseling if the spouse continues to stonewall or refuse to connect emotionally.

Not all expectations in marriage are wrong. Today on the blog I talked about 4 things it's okay to expect in marriage. It's a good antidote from the teaching that if you're sad and lonely, it's because you're in sin.

So he DESPERATELY needs respect, while she merely DESIRES love.

And so starts the problems with Love & Respect.

To give one example: 
Emerson Eggerichs talks about how his wife kept putting pepper on the eggs even though he told her he didn't like them that way. He says, "she didn't mean to be disrespectful...", but she was.

Later, his wife keeps asking him to stop putting wet towels on the bed. 

And in this case, who is disrespectful?

Why, she is, of course, for asking him to stop!

So when he asks her to stop something and she forgets, she's being disrespectful. When she asks him to stop something, and he forgets, she's STILL being disrespectful.

This double standard is one of the things that I note in this summary one-page of the problems with Love & Respect. 
We also look at how he downplays abuse; demands wives give unconditional respect even when he has been abusive; when he has withering rage that scares her; when he has been drinking and straying.

And we note that unconditional respect includes giving sex on demand; putting him in authority and hierarchy over her; and listening to his opinions over hers because she is more deceived since she is a woman.

And, of course, we explain why the book scored 0/48 on our rubric of healthy sexuality.

Please, DOWNLOAD this summary and give it to your pastor, your counselor, your friend, your small group leader.
Together, we can call the evangelical church to more!

80% of murderers are male, but that doesn't mean that 80% of males are murderers.

Remember back to grade 3 or 4 math? You likely learned this lesson--poodles are dogs, but not all dogs are poodles. 

Well, John Gottman found that 85% of people who stonewall are male. 

But how does Emerson Eggerichs talk about this in Love & Respect?

He says that Gottman found that 85% of men stonewall--something he freely admits he has problems with. And he tells women they should understand that men who stonewall are being honourable. 

Interestingly, on his blog he has also quoted the number the correct way--that 85% of stonewallers are male.

By making stonewalling sound normal, though, it gives cover to guys who do it. 

I'm amazed that no one has called him out on this basic math and logic problem since the book was published.

But there's a lot wrong with Love & Respect, not just math.

What if....we're actually supposed to be following God?

What if submission is less about doing what someone else wants, and more about submitting to what God wants for both of you? What if submission is about putting what someone else really needs first?

Not what someone else wants. Not what will make someone's life really easy. Not what will enable sin in any way.

But instead what will actually help them?

Think about it: God says that we are to seek Him FIRST. We pray for God's will to be done on earth, and that includes in our marriages. It's God's will that we're always to focus on.

Why, then, do we think that women should focus on a husband's will?

If we believe that, then we think a husband's will trumps God's will.

There's a word for that.

Idolatry.

The Bible tells us to submit to one another (Ephesians 5:21). We care for each other (Galatians 6:2); consider others needs before our own (Philippians 2:3-4), love others as ourselves (Mark 12:31).
It does not tell us to allow ourselves to be treated as a slave, or to enable selfishness, or to ignore God's voice in favor of our husband's.

God is on the throne. Let's keep him there.

Every now and then I hear a story that stops me in my tracks.

I often think I've heard it all. But this woman's story still felt like a gut punch.

She reached out after I wrote some posts about marital rape in the fall. And her story was so heartbreaking--not just for what her husband did, but even more so how the church felt that they had the right to punish her for wanting to get to safety.

In this week's podcast, I read the letter this woman sent the pastor. He knew the details of this marriage.

And he still felt there was no grounds for divorce.

He punished her--not the one who had been raping his wife.

Then this brave woman joins me and tells us how she has found Jesus again! And how her life is going now that she is free--free from her husband; free from abuse; and also free of toxic church spaces.

Her story has so many similarities to the ones coming out of John MacArthur's church. Over and over again abused women being told they need to return to the abuse, suffer for Jesus, and submit more.

This isn't of God. And we need to speak up. We need to stop supporting churches that handle abuse like this. We need to bring awareness to what is happening.

And we need to say, no more.

Can I tell you what my awesome husband Keith wrote this week?

He's been on fire for the last little while about how badly the evangelical church has treated women, and how weak men have puffed themselves up by trying to keep women small.

This week he wrote a post for the Bare Marriage blog about how often we cherry pick Bible verses and take them out of context, rather than looking at the whole of Scripture. He said:

"When you see a verse from Paul that implies women should never teach or have authority over men and then see several verses where he commends women in leadership positions, let me suggest that the appropriate response is to be humble enough to recognize that maybe what Paul was saying in 1 Timothy 2 isn’t what you thought.

And when you continue to insist that 1 Timothy 2:12 is straightforward and anyone who wants to take a second look at what Paul might have meant is “unbiblical”, you do not show your devotion – you show your ignorance. 

And most of all, if you demand a “plain reading” of verses that support what you believe, then throw plain reading out the window and go through mental gymnastics to explain away other Scriptures that don’t, then quite simply you are not interested in understanding the Bible, you are only interested in using it as a tool to prove what you have already decided to believe."

It's awesome. Please read the whole thing!

Is marriage "hard"?

There is a huge difference between life's difficulties that you handle together, and one spouse actually causing difficulties for another.

And yet far too often we combine everything into "storms"--the loss of a child; a miscarriage; a spouse's porn use.

One of those things is not like the other.

Abuse, affairs, porn use, chronic gambling, laziness, selfishness--these are not "marriage storms.' These are destructive actions by one spouse against another.

I have lost a child. I have actually endured "marriage storms." And my husband was right there beside me, hurting with me, holding my hand, going through it together.

That's entirely different than trying to process a spouse's betrayal.

I am not saying that healing after betrayal is impossible--though it does require true repentance on the part of the spouse has done the wrong, and a rebuilding of trust. But I am saying that categorizing all of these things as "normal marriage problems" and telling people "marriage is hard" does a disservice.

LIFE is hard. Marriage adds extra elements of complexity because now you have another person in the mix, and often kids in the mix, and you can have job losses and health crises and so many other things.

But that's entirely different from one spouse's actions making life difficult and untenable for the other. Let's not mix this up.

Do women REALLY talk more than men do?

Last week on episode 182 of the Bare Marriage podcast we jumped into the debate, “do girls talk too much?”

It was one of the toxic beliefs we measured in our survey of 7000+ women for our upcoming book She Deserves Better. When you believe as a teenager that “girls talk too much” and that you should stop talking, it’s highly associated with lower self-esteem, worse marriages when you grow up—even having a very unequal division of labor in your marriage!

But where did this idea come from? Well, we traced it back to James Dobson in 1983, when he claimed that women speak 25,000 words a day compared to men’s 12,000. He used this claim to say that men are talked out when they get home from work.

And countless others repeated the claim, often using different numbers.

No one cited any studies.

When researchers looked at it, guess what? Women and men speak virtually the same number of words.

EXCEPT in mixed groups. Then men speak the vast majority of words.

Women don’t talk too much. They need permission to speak up.

And the idea that we can’t expect our men to want to talk to us is toxic, and hurts relationships.

In our new book She Deserves Better, we look in detail at the effects when girls internalize the idea that they should talk less, be smaller, don’t take up so much space.

Your daughter needs your permission to be big!

If you're going to call yourself a counselor, you need to understand trauma responses.

And yet far too many who are trained in the biblical counseling model do not.

I'm not saying that all biblical counselors don't understand trauma. But the ACBC (Association of Certified Biblical Counselors) is not safe. As Rachael Denhollander once said, she has yet to meet a sexual assault survivor who has gone to see a biblical counselor who has not ended up more harmed.

I'm not saying that Christian counselors are bad. But we need to see licensed counselors. "Biblical" Counseling is a specific methodology of counseling that eschews modern psychology and focuses on Scripture for a counseling manual. It tends to frame issues in terms of sin or lack of faith. And often its practitioners do not understand trauma.

Because there is no licensing, there are not professional standards in the same way. You cannot lose your license for violating ethical guidelines. 

There are no privacy guarantees the way there are with someone who is licensed.

I know many biblical counselors truly mean well. But I'd encourage anyone who feels called to go into counseling to please get proper training in evidence-based counseling methods. You can be a Christian and still go the licensed route. 

Every week I get new emails from people who have been harmed by biblical counseling at their church. This is too important to not do well.

First, anyone notice the strange wording? "Are you willing..." makes it sound like if you don't do it, there's something wrong with you. 

And "frame" is an odd word. It implies that you're making something seem different than it actually is. (Also, a dad doesn't need to be a hero. He just needs to be a normal, good person). 

But beyond that: 

One of the best gifts you can give your kids is the ability to see truth and speak truth.

Too often churches (and orgs like Focus on the Family) give messages like this one: Women, it's your job to make sure your kids think their dad is a hero. 

Now, it's a very good idea to focus on good things and to not needlessly bad mouth a parent to your kids. It's a very good idea to show your kids how much you appreciate their dad.

But many men are NOT good dads. And if you tell your kids that they're supposed to think of their dad as a hero when he is not--you're actually gaslighting your kids.

You're telling them: "Your experience of your dad isn't valid. The feelings you have with your dad aren't valid. You need to think of him as wonderful regardless of how he treats you or makes you feel."

This primes them to think they can't trust their feelings. This primes them to ignore red flags. 

As we showed in She Deserves Better, this actually primes girls to get into abusive relationships.
If your husband or ex-husband is treating your kids badly, it's okay for this to be acknowledged in your family.

We need to stop spreading messages like this one from Focus on the Family without any caveats. It isn't okay, and our kids need to know they can see the truth and speak the truth.
And they'll only know that if we model it.

Want to learn how? Check out Chapters 2-4 in She Deserves Better, as well as the chapter on how to identify and talk about toxic people!

Ever feel like you just need wings?

For the last few years I've felt like a worker ant, with my head down, not stopping, trying to get things done. 

And I have! Together with my two amazing co-authors, I've written The Great Sex Rescue and She Deserves Better. I've written The Good Girl's Guide to Great Sex and The Good Guy's Guide to Great Sex.

We've done surveys. I've done so many interviews.

I've tried so, so hard to change the evangelical conversation about sex.

But ever since Shiny, Happy People released, I've felt something different.

I've felt lighter, like something is actually happening.

I stopped and looked up.

There's lots going on behind the scenes. Some awesome people are noticing our work--and changing how they teach.

And I've had some AMAZING notes from readers this week.
One woman wrote about how she finally figured out what an orgasm was after 16 years of marriage by reading The Great Sex Rescue!

So I feel lighter.

I know it's been heavy with all the terrible things Shiny, Happy People revealed, and with recent news stories about women once again being marginalized in evangelicalism.

But I think, before something big happens, God does a big a shaking. He does a big sifting. The rotten stuff has to come to light so that everyone can see it, recognize it for what it is, and deliberately choose the other side.

That's when freedom comes.

I hope this summer I'll have more time to just look up at what God is doing and use my wings!

Because sometimes we need a break, and we get to stop working so hard and just fly.

Do we understand that God won't violate free will?

This week on the blog and on episode 197 of the Bare Marriage podcast we've been looking at the book Power of a Praying Wife by Stormie Omartian. And one of the big issues with it is that she says that wives are called to pray for husbands to be released from abusive and addictive behaviors--and that you have to believe that God will do this, and you have to promise never, ever to leave, before our prayers will work.

But you cannot pray hard enough for your husband to change, because that's not in your power or God's power. He won't change your husband if your husband doesn't want to be changed.

All week I've been hearing from heartbroken women who stayed 10 years, 15 years, even 30 years in an abusive marriage because they thought if they just prayed enough....maybe God would work.

They felt they were bad Christians. They felt God didn't love them.

But maybe God just wanted to free them.

We had an amazing conversation about this on episode 197 of the Bare Marriage podcast that dropped today!

Power of a Praying Wife meant well.

I know Stormie Omartian wanted to help women.

But ever since I started talking about it on Wednesday, I've been inundated on how that book was the impetus for women staying in abusive marriages for 10, 15, 25 years. 

It made women even in relatively healthy marriages think direct communication was wrong, and instead of speaking up they should "shut up and pray."

I think what's so hard is that women wanted to follow God. 

They believed the book because they loved Jesus and wanted to please Him.

And so they prayed. And prayed. And prayed.

And when their marriage didn't change, they thought God had abandoned them. They thought God was upset at them. 

God, who had been their safe haven, became the angry school marm telling them they weren't good enough.

No, that wasn't the intention.

But it was the result.

We can do better than this now. 

I feel so badly for the women who now struggle to read the Bible or pray at all (I've heard from many of you this week, too!).

I just want to tell you: I get it. 

When I realized how empty and wrong so much of the advice around marriage was in the evangelical church, and how hurtful so many teachers were, it was devastating.

For years, all I could do was read the gospels. Anything else was too triggering. But I could look at Jesus. I could see how He related to people. I could see how He would never, ever tell a postpartum, exhausted woman married to a rage filled husband that she needed to give him a blow job or else she was depriving him.

And I could see that anyone who thought God would say that didn't know Jesus at all.

I pray that you will see God anew--that He isn't the angry school marm. He is the Jesus who shows such compassion. 

I'm sorry that, in your zeal to serve Him, you were ever told otherwise.

Is your marriage about impression management or about truth? Are you aiming for health of all kinds—spiritual, emotional, relational?

Can I tell you about the rose-coloured glasses effect? Women who grow up in conservative churches are more likely to tell themselves "my marriage is great" and "my sex life is great" even when the objective measures of these things AREN'T great. 

We found that, when you look ONLY at wives who don't reach orgasm, those who believe in hiearchy in marriage are 22% more likely to say they're satisfied with the frequency of their orgasm (ie: NONE) as those who believe in mutuality and partnership.

And so much more! It makes sense. When you're told that your identity as a woman is in being a wife and a mother, you're more likely to try to convince yourself--and others--that your marriage is perfect, even when it isn't.

This week on the podcast we talked about a different approach. 

Jesus is the Way, the TRUTH, and the Life.

Why ignore the orgasm gap? Or marital rape? Or sexual pain?

We have an orgasm gap of 47 points--where 95% of men almost always/always reach orgasm, but only 48% of evangelical women do. 

Let’s take a step back, though. If these teachers truly believe that sex is amazing (which they say all the time), then why would women not want it?

So either sex ISN'T amazing, or women are crazy.

And it seems like too often they choose, "there's something wrong with women."

Well, there's not. In fact, our bodies tell a story. When our bodies feel little desire, there's a reason. They're exhausted. They're overworked. They're in pain. They don't feel safe.

Our study for The Great Sex Rescue found that when:

1. Women frequently reach orgasm
2. Women feel emotionally connected during sex
3. The couple shares high marital satisfaction
4. There's no porn use in the marriage
5. There's no sexual dysfunction

Then frequency takes care of itself. Frequency or low libido don't tend to be the problems. They're a SIGN that there is something else going on.

So please, Christian authors. Stop complaining about women's low libidos, and start talking about the things that tank women's libidos: Not understanding her pleasure. Not caring about her pain. Making her feel used. Making her feel like a porn substitute. Making her feel like you only want her for what she can do for you, rather than for a whole partnership. Spreading messages that make sex sound like an obligation. Not helping her get evidence-based help for sexual trauma.

We can do better than this! And it's always so encouraging to hear from people who have found The Great Sex Rescue so freeing--including so many guys.

I said goodbye to you 27 years ago today.

I've now lived more years since you left me, little one, than I did before you entered our lives.

Today is the anniversary of my baby boy's death. He died after surgery to correct a heart defect. So we're having a melancholy weekend, and I'm reminded again how the body does indeed keep the score.

The morning of Christopher's surgery, I went to the hospital at 5:00 a.m. because I couldn't sleep. And I held him and prayed over him, and sang over him.

The song I sang the most was the theme song of the movie Babe. My oldest daughter Rebecca, who was 19 months at the time, watched this movie constantly, so it was always in my head.

And the words to this were my wish for my son.

It went like this:

If I had words to make a day for you,
I'd sing you a morning golden and new.
I would make that day last for all time,
And fill the night deep in moonshine.

I would have done anything to give him more time; to take the pain away; to have him enjoy life. But I couldn't.

Sometimes life is just really, really hard.

I'm grateful that my husband and I leaned on each other at the time. I'm grateful we had Rebecca to make us smile even in our grief. And I'm grateful that my daughter Katie came along so soon afterwards.

I'm glad he now is in a place where the morning is golden and new, and where that day lasts for all time. 

But it still hurts.

So I'm going to take a bit of a quiet day today.

I still hold you close, baby.

But this isn't character training. This is teaching them that they aren't safe, and so they will do what they have to do to feel safe.

When we interpret everything a child does that we don't like as "rebellion" rather than recognizing that they are small little beings who often don't even realize that they are separate from us yet, and may not even have a theory of mind yet, we are the ones doing the harm. Do words matter?

I think they do.

Let's say that most who claim to be complementarian (where the husband is in authority and makes the final decision) actually practice mutuality, where you seek after the Holy Spirit together and make decisions together.

So your marriage will be healthy and look happy.

But imagine that you tell others that you believe in male hierarchy.

Some of the people you tell that to will act it out.

They will think that's the secret to your success, because they won't know that's not actually how you act.

And if they act it out--their chance of divorce skyrockets. 
Their chance of abuse increases. Their marital satisfaction tends to plummet.

What would happen if you simply told the truth?

What if you told people that you sought out God together, and that you functioned as a team?
Then people would follow that--and would tend to do well.

Those who practice mutuality tend to do well. Those who practice hierarchy don't.

So, please, words matter. 

Preach what you practice. If you practice mutuailty, tell people. Don't just say you're complementarian because everyone around you preaches it. 

Set people free. Let other people enjoy the kind of marriage you enjoy--because they practice mutuality too.

Is there some playbook somewhere where evangelical authors all got together and decided to call sex "sexual release"--and specifically a husband's sexual release?

Emerson Eggerichs does it in Love & Respect. Power of a Praying Wife does it. And Steve Arterburn does it repeatedly.

This is bizarre. This passage from Every Heart Restored makes this claim that the Bible promises the husband sexual release, referring to 1 Corinthians 7:3-5, while 1 Peter 3 promises the wife honor.

Have they actually read 1 Corinthians 7? Because guess what? If you're going to say it promises the husband sexual release, then you've got to be honest and say that it promises the wife this too. In the passage, everything he gets, she also gets.

Now, I think this is such an anemic view of sex, and not what this passage is talking about. Sex in the Bible is something that is supposed to be mutual, intimate, and pleasurable for both. If sex is merely about his physical release, and she's just being used as a masturbatory tool, then she isn't getting anything intimate or pleasurable, and it certainly isn't mutual. So she's already being deprived. 

How about we develop a healthier, richer view of sex that is better than this pornified, sex-doll type sex that too many evangelical books portray?

That's what we did in The Great Sex Rescue!

Okay, who is the one being selfish here?

So the husband wakes up early in the morning and wakes his wife up for sex, and she's the selfish one if she says she's still tired?

Prioritizing his climax over her legitimate need for sleep when they obviously have young children is an incredibly bad take, and it's one of the reasons that the vast majority of Christian sex books scored in the harmful category on our healthy sexuality rubric.

Look, there's nothing wrong with morning sex! Lots of people LOVE it, and if you're one of those couples, go for it!

But to write in a book that it is healthy and normal to wake up one's exhausted spouse early for sex, and that it is selfish if they are prioritizing sleep before the children wake up, sets the stage for men to be painted as hard done by when she says, "please don't wake the kids and let me keep sleeping."

What if he instead said, "let's have sex, and I'll get up with the kids and you can sleep in?" Or, better yet, if he said that THE NIGHT BEFORE. 

Just because one has an erection does not mean that one's spouse has to then take care of it.

Sex is something that is mutual, intimate, and pleasurable for both. The scenario that Leman is painting here has absolutely nothing to do with her experience, and focuses only on his. That's not mutual, not intimate, and not pleasurable for both.

Let's work at creating healthy marriages where great sex flows as a culmination of a great relationship--one where you respect each other, including their need for sleep.

You are a data point. 

We are all data points. Our stories are important. But we are individuals, and we could be the exception to the rule.

When Paul wrote "it is better to marry than to burn" in 1 Corinthians 7:9, he was writing into a context where the Christian community was thinking that celibacy was holier than marriage. And Paul was saying: "Look, you don't have to remain celibate. If you feel the pull to marriage, get married! If you have a sexual drive, it's okay to marry."

He was not saying, "Don't worry about self-control! A wife can fix that for you!"

Self-control is a fruit of the Spirit. Nowhere in Scripture does it say that we don't have to worry about sexual sin and self-control because we can just use our spouses as sin management tools.

No, Scripture calls for sex to be a deep "knowing" of each other, not a using.

Scripture tells us to put to death sexual immorality.

The fact that so many men like him think that the Bible teaches that men don't need self-control because that's what wives are for--well, they're telling on themselves.

They've telling you what they think of women.

They're telling you what they think of sex (and how shallow they are about it).

And you can likely make more conclusions.

Can we please make it that next time someone says something this offensive and anti-Christ, that the pushback is immense? 

This can't be okay in the church.
It just can't.

I met one of my heroes!

Recently, while I was in Michigan, I had the opportunity to meet Rosemarie Aquilina, the judge in the Larry Nassar case.

I watched that trial live, and was blown away by her clarity in dealing with Nassar, but most of all by the way she insisted on giving victims a voice, and in encouraging them after they shared their stories.

I asked her how she got to be so brave, and she told the story of how she felt that her voice and choice had been taken from her when she was a child, and now she's dedicated to giving victims voices where she can, and in educating other members of the judiciary in how to handle abuse and spot abusers.

The world needs more people like her.

While watching the Nassar trial, I was also blown away by @rachaeldenhollander ‘s brave victim impact statement. She bravely added her name first so that others could find their voice.

I'm thinking of Rachael this week, along with others who are fighting for the Southern Baptist Convention of churches to listen to victims and give them justice, especially now that the SBC has filed an amicus brief in Kentucky arguing against the rights of survivors, and protecting institutions. The SBC argued for keeping the statute of limitations, in a case that they weren't even involved in, so that they could shield themselves in lawsuits that are coming soon. 

So many survivors have been working so hard to pressure the SBC to do the right thing, and this week was a monumental betrayal, and a real blow. At the same time that the SBC was saying all the right words about standing for victims, their lawyers were throwing victims under the bus.

May we all have the spirit of Rosemarie Aquilina, who looked evil right in the eye and said, "I'm going to make sure every victim has their turn in court. I'm going to make sure every victim's story is told."

When institutions betray you, so many are still working tirelessly to make sure the right thing is done. May God give them strength, especially in hard weeks like these.

I fixed this Al Mohler quote earlier, but I thought I'd fix it in an entirely new way!

The first time around, I made it about the fact that he had signed on to a legal document arguing that child sexual abuse victims shouldn't get to sue the entitles that covered up abuse if the statute of limitations had elapsed. 

But many of you noted that the original, about sex ed, was problematic in and of itself.

And I agree. Let me share what our survey of 7000 predominantly evangelical women for our book She Deserves Better showed: There is absolutely no downside to more information.

The more sex ed terms girls knew when they graduated high school; whether they knew a female orgasm existed (because 40% of women didn't); whether they were unashamed of their period; whether they understood consent--the more information, the higher the self-esteem, the less likelihood of having multiple sexual partners, the less likelihood of being abused, the less likelihood of marrying an abuser, the higher likelihood of having high marital and sexual satisfaction later.

Information is important.

I understand that many are worried about what the public schools are teaching about sex ed. But let me tell you about generations: my generation (Gen X) had better sex ed than Millennials did. As we've rejected sex ed in schools, we haven't replaced it with actual sex ed in churches or Christian schools. We've merely told kids, "don't do it." 

That's not enough. When that's the majority of the message, girls do badly long term.

Girls deserve better than this. 

So rather than railing against public schools for what they're doing wrong, let's admit that we are raising in the church girls with a 250% higher chance of sexual pain disorders; with more anorgasmia; and with articiially lowered libidos. 

We're not doing well either.

Sex ed matters. Our girls deserve better.

Let's say you have an awesome marriage, and you also believe that the wife should submit to her husband, and that the husband is the leader.

You say you believe that, but in actual practice you both submit to each other. You love each other, you're kind to each other, you defer to each other.

But the message you give your kids is: God made men to lead and women to submit, and this is beautiful.

In chapter 6 of She Deserves Better, "She Deserves to Be Protected", we talked about this phenomenon. 

Let's say your daughter believes what you teach her. She grows up, and she meets a guy who is controlling. But she sees it as "he's a strong leader." He doesn't really listen to her opinions, but she thinks, "That's okay, because I'm supposed to learn to submit to him. That's what God wants me to do."

So she misses the red flags.

And they get married, and she ends up in abusive relationship.

She believed your words. But you didn't actually act out your words. She has, and it's hurt her.

Last week I got a letter from a former pastor. He spent 40 years in the pulpit, teaching about complementarianism and male headship. And he and his wife have spent the last five years trying to help their daughter escape an abusive marriage.

He now regrets teaching complementarianism. He and his wife were egalitarians in practice. But now he sees how dangerous it is to tell women that they must submit to a husband's leadership, instead of teaching that both are to submit to God, and that women's voices matter just as much as men's voices do.

Please, if you're in a good marriage, don't preach to your kids something different than what you actually practice. 

Teach them about love and equality and mutual service, as you humbly serve Jesus together. 

That's the way forward.

Are MEN bad marriage prospects if they're independent?

Nope.

Driscoll wants women to be dependent, but men to be independent.

Because independent women make bad wives, he thinks.

Yet do you know what women have the lowest divorce rate and most stable, happy marriages? Educated women, especially those with graduate degrees. 

Do you know which women have the highest divorce rate, and often the worst marital outcomes? Women with very little education who have a hard time supporting themselves. 

Also women who marry younger (as Driscoll wants women to do).

I'm not against young marriages (I married young). But we need to look at the facts.

Women who have choices, who marry because they want to, who are able to choose a good husband because they have the option to stay single if they need to--they tend to marry well.

BUT--and this is a big but--when marriages get abusive, or where there is substance abuse, they also leave much faster.

Which makes you wonder: does Driscoll want women uneducated and dependent because he honestly thinks this makes better marriages? Or is it because these women are easier to control, and are less likely to leave if men get domineering? 

Given his theology, I'd say it's the latter.

Nobody should ever marry because they can't handle life alone and feel like they need rescuing or protecting. Marry because you want to, because you love someone with good character. 

Make sure that you can stand on your own two feet, because this is better for everyone in the long run. Even if you don't work outside the home, try to get some sort of skill or credentials so that you could if you needed to (you never know when your spouse may get ill).

But women don't need rescuing. And a man who feels threatened by an independent woman is a man who isn't interested in a real relationship of partners, but merely wants someone he can control. And THAT will lead to a bad marriage--not the fact that she has an education and is confident in herself.

Look, I’m happy for that woman whose marriage was restored—although I’m super worried for her, and no one should ever give a testimony like this about a man jailed for domestic violence and not give MAJOR caveats. 

I would also like to check in with her five years down the road and see if things are still okay.

But it really bugs me when the only acceptable testimonies when it comes to difficult marriages are, “we got over everything, including all the abuse or addictions or whatever else was going on, and now everything is even better than before!”

That is simply not most people’s stories.

Pretending it is is dangerous. 

And isn’t it just as much a victory when people find real peace again, even if they’re divorced? 

Isn’t it just as much a victory when someone is rescued from a horrible situation—and their kids are, too?

And maybe if we talked about these things as victories, then more churches would come alongside women leaving abusive marriages and actually support them, rather than rebuking them, ignoring them, or even excommunicating them (it happens).

Marriage is not the goal. Jesus is.

And Jesus can still be praised, honored, and served, even if the marriage falls apart.
